assignments.summary: The provided HTML describes a university assignment for a computer science course. The assignment is related to heaps and heapsort, and students are instructed to refer to a PDF file (lga-24-heap.pdf) for detailed instructions. The assignment is supported by readings from the CLRS textbook, specifically Chapter 6 on Heapsort, and several lecture videos covering topics such as priority queues, heaps introduction, heap operations, and heapsort. The videos are accompanied by slides and descriptions, providing students with a comprehensive understanding of the subject matter. An answer key for the assignment is promised to be available soon.

assignments.name: HW9
assignments.description:
This is an individual assignment - do not show your work or any solutions to your peers in any section of CSCI 341, only discuss concepts and ideas, per the CS@Mines Collaboration Policy. Please visit office hours for assistance or arrange a time to meet an instructor or TA.

Download homework problems in PDF format and follow the instructions within it.  A txt file containing outputs of public test cases is also provided. Please save your file and name it hw9.s.

Submit your completed homework using the link below that will take you to Gradescope.
assignments.summary: This is an individual university assignment for the CSCI 341 course, where students are required to complete homework problems found in a downloadable PDF file. The assignment must be completed individually, with no collaboration or sharing of work with peers, as per the CS@Mines Collaboration Policy. Students can seek assistance during office hours or by arranging a meeting with an instructor or TA. The completed homework should be saved as "hw9.s" and submitted through Gradescope, along with a provided output file for reference.

assignments.name: Reading Week 12
assignments.description:
Chapter 9  (Pg. 480-537)
9.1  Introduction
9.2  Payback Period Analysis
9.3  Savings Are Analogous to Income 
9.4  Sunk Costs and Opportunity Costs 
9.5  Breakeven Analyses
9.6  Three Methods of Investment Valuation 
9.7  NPV Use for Breakeven Acquisition Cost Valuation 
9.7a NPV Use for Breakeven Sale Value Analysis 
9.8  Valuation of Public Projects and Investments 
9.9  Cash Flow Versus Shareholder Reporting and Net Income
9.10  Net Income Criteria Compared to Cash Flow Criteria
9.10a Value Added

Chapter 10 (Pg. 551-575)

10.1 General Replacement Philosophy
10.2 Leasing Compared to Purchasing
10.3 Sunk Costs and Opportunity Costs Related to Replacement
assignments.summary: The provided HTML describes a university assignment covering chapters 9 and 10 of a textbook. Chapter 9 focuses on various financial analysis topics, including payback period, breakeven analysis, investment valuation, and cash flow versus shareholder reporting. The chapter is divided into 10 sections, each exploring a different aspect of financial decision-making. Chapter 10, on the other hand, discusses general replacement philosophy, leasing compared to purchasing, and sunk costs and opportunity costs related to replacement, covering sections 10.1 to 10.3. Overall, the assignment appears to be related to financial management and decision-making.

assignments.name: Amazon Pays No Tax "Write to Learn"
assignments.description:
Watch the following video and then write two observations and a question.

 

https://www.cnbc.com/2019/04/03/why-amazon-paid-no-federal-income-tax.html 

 

Please put thought into your observations and question as this is a graded activity.  One page maximum for your two observations and question.

 

You will be peer reviewing three other peoples response.  Please respond to each persons observations as well as try to answer their question.  Your grade however will come from your submission, and not the peer review.
assignments.summary: The assignment requires students to watch a video and then submit a write-up with two observations and a question. The video appears to be related to a CNBC article about why Amazon paid no federal income tax. Students are asked to put thought into their submissions, which should be no more than one page in length. Additionally, students will be required to peer review the submissions of three other students, responding to their observations and attempting to answer their question, although their own grade will be based on their initial submission.

assignments.name: HW10
assignments.description:
This is an individual assignment - do not show your work or any solutions to your peers in any section of CSCI 341, only discuss concepts and ideas, per the CS@Mines Collaboration Policy Download CS@Mines Collaboration PolicyDownload CS@Mines Collaboration PolicyDownload CS@Mines Collaboration Policy. Please visit office hours for assistance or arrange a time to meet an instructor or TA.

Download homework problems in PDF Download PDFor WORD Download WORDformat and follow the instructions within it.

It's fine to handwrite & scan your work, just keep it legible. Make sure your name is on the pages submitted.  Please use the same number of pages as the PDF file and each page should have the same problems as the PDF file.

Please create a PDF named CSCI341_HW10_YourName.pdf, replacing "YourName" with your name -- i.e., if Susan Jones were submitting work, she would create and submit CSCI341_HW10_SusanJones.pdf.

Submit your completed homework using the link below that will take you to Gradescope.
assignments.summary: This is an individual assignment for the CSCI 341 course, where students are required to complete homework problems and submit them in a specific format. The problems can be downloaded in PDF or Word format, and students are expected to follow the instructions provided in the file. The submission should be a PDF named CSCI341_HW10_YourName.pdf, with the student's name replacing "YourName". The PDF should have the same number of pages as the original file, with each page containing the same problems. Students can handwrite and scan their work, but it must be legible and include their name on each page. The completed homework should be submitted through the Gradescope link provided.

assignments.name: In-Class Quiz After-Tax
assignments.description:
The quiz will happen on one class period this week.  

The following quiz has five questions.  The final question contains our in-class problem we are going to work.  Please answer the first four basic tax questions and then download the file in question 5.  Remember to submit your quiz after you download the file.
assignments.summary: The quiz for the university assignment will take place during one class period and consists of five questions. The first four questions are basic tax questions, and the fifth question involves an in-class problem that requires downloading a file. Students are instructed to answer the first four questions, download the file for the fifth question, and then submit their quiz.

assignments.name: Exam 2
assignments.description:
Exam 2 is a common (evening) exam.

Date: Tuesday, April 8

Time: 7:00 - 8:30pm

Exam rooms (same as Exam 1):

Sections C, D (M/W class days): Green Center Metals Hall

Sections A, B (T/R class days): CTLM 102

Exam 2 will cover Sections 2.4, 2.5, 2.6, 3.1, 3.2, 3.3, and 3.4.

Homeworks 7 (#5 and #6) and HW 8, 9, 10, and 11 cover Exam 2 material.

Formula sheet: M334_Exam2_FormulaSheet.pdf will be provided with Exam 2.

Review problems: PracticeProblems_Ch2_Ch3_334.pdf

Review session Monday, April 7, 5:00 - 7:30 (room TBA).
assignments.summary: The university assignment is for Exam 2, scheduled to take place on Tuesday, April 8, from 7:00 to 8:30 pm. The exam will cover sections 2.4, 2.5, 2.6, 3.1, 3.2, 3.3, and 3.4, and students can refer to homeworks 7, 8, 9, 10, and 11 for relevant material. A formula sheet will be provided during the exam, and review problems are available for practice. A review session will be held on Monday, April 7, from 5:00 to 7:30 pm, with the room to be announced. The exam will take place in either the Green Center Metals Hall for sections C and D, or CTLM 102 for sections A and B.

assignments.name: HW#10 - Track Homework
assignments.description:
Homework #10 is a track Homework and in fact is the same homework as HW#4 but after-tax.  

You MUST use the same homework you choose for HW#4.  If you switch problems you will receive a zero.

Each problem statement has had the necessary tax details added to the problem.  For each and every problem the deductions will start in the year the cost is incurred and the company has "other income".

Your model should balance, check Rule #4!

HW#10 Aerospace.pdf

HW#10 General.pdf

HW#10 Mining.pdf

HW#10 Oil and Gas.pdf

HW#10 Technology.pdf
assignments.summary: Homework #10 is a track homework that is the same as Homework #4 but with tax details added. Students must use the same homework they chose for HW#4, and switching problems will result in a zero. The deductions will start in the year the cost is incurred, and the company has "other income". The model should balance, and students can refer to the provided PDF files for Aerospace, General, Mining, Oil and Gas, and Technology for the problem statements.

plan: To tackle the upcoming assignments, I'll create a study plan. This week, I'll focus on reviewing Heaps and priority queues for LGA 24 on Monday and completing HW9 by the deadline. Next, I'll prioritize Practice Problems Week 12, Reading Week 12, and other assignments due on Friday, 04. I'll allocate Tuesday to Thursday for studying and completing HW10, WSJ Week 11, and other assignments. The following week, I'll review for the In-Class Quiz After-Tax on Tuesday and Exam 2. I'll then dedicate time to completing Practice Problems Week 13, Reading Week 13, and WSJ Week 12 by Friday, 11, while also tracking HW#10. By breaking down the tasks and managing my time effectively, I'll be able to meet all the deadlines and stay on top of my coursework.
